author: notmcd
content: I would love to run a validator on avado, any ELI5 tips?

author: donschoe
content: What I do is compile lighthouse or prysm binaries on my workstation and then distribute them to less powerfull boxes. This avoids taking up lots of processing time and disk space for toolchains on the validator nodes.

author: donschoe
content: Have you read the Schlesi docs yet?

author: protolambda
content: I tried building static binaries of prysm and lighthouse, but no luck on either. Bazel is not liking static Go flags, and has dependencies that are shared libs etc. And lighthouse requires openssl, which I can't seem to get statically linked in.

author: protolambda
content: But docker should still work to have a reasonably lightweight but portable build

author: donschoe
content: ok interesting

author: donschoe
content: I just run bazel build

author: donschoe
content: and take the stripped binaries

author: donschoe
content: but I'm using Archlinux on all of my boxes, so I didn't even have thr chance to notice they are not statically linked

author: donschoe
content: <3 Arch

author: protolambda
content: Running arch too. And the whole lighthouse team too. Lol

author: protolambda
content: But yes, not statically linked. Probably also need glibc and whatnot

author: protolambda
content: At least Rumor and zrnt can be compiled statically, and have dockerfiles for a liblinux image of just a few MB üôÇ
